pr_title: [Offline sync] Allow user to specify connection type for sync

timeline.message: Add shared pref filename and mode to Config.java

Use the same config in SettingsFragment

 - This makes all shared prefs stored via SettingsFragment accessible through LocalValueStore across the application.
Add getter for the network constraint in LocalValueStore
Create BaseWorkManager and add template for requests/constraints

Refactor child WorkManager classes

 - Simplify by removing duplicate code
 - If no custom config is needed, then use base template. Otherwise, override appropriate methods

timeline.bodyText:
We might want to change this to shouldUploadMediaOverUnmeteredConnectionOnly. Whilst most Wi-Fi connections are unmetered some are not (hotspot tethering, airport Wi-Fi), also with 5G there are some mobile connections which are unmetered.
My point being: we're presumably trying to avoid the user being charged for data rather than simply letting them choose a specific network protocol.
timeline.author: dturner

replies.bodyText: Thanks for pointing that out. So does that mean I should update the label in the settings as well?
replies.author: shobhitagarwal1612

replies.bodyText: Good catch, @dturner. Google Photos and other apps still prompt the user to "Wait for Wi-Fi" rather than "Wait for Unmetered connection". The latter is harder to explain to beginner users - @sergeydolgov1 do you think we should use "Wi-Fi" as a proxy for "Unmetered Network" in the UIs, even though it's not really 100% correct?
replies.author: gino-m

replies.bodyText: @gino-m Suggest that we use "Wi-Fi" as a proxy for Unmetered Network as Wi-Fi is usually the way people use the Internet free of charge. Also, FYI -- this is Android developer documentation, they also use "Wi-Fi" terminology: https://developer.android.com/training/basics/network-ops/managing
replies.author: sergeydolgov1

timeline.author: dturner

timeline.bodyText: Out of interest, what caused this to become public?
timeline.author: dturner

replies.bodyText: At first, I reused the same variable SHARED_PREFERENCES_NAME in the SettingsFragment, but then moved it Config.java. So this can be reverted back now. Nice catch!
replies.author: shobhitagarwal1612

timeline.bodyText: Any reason for picking LINEAR backoff? I thought the generally accepted best practice was to use EXPONENTIAL
timeline.author: dturner

replies.bodyText:
This is the current backoff criteria being used in DataSyncWorkManager. I just pulled it out and moved to BaseWorkerManager so we can apply a common template to all of our *WorkManager and move boiler-plate code to this base class.
But I do agree EXPONENTIAL seems to be the best practice. @gino-m Could you please provide some background why it LINEAR was set as the default choice?
replies.author: shobhitagarwal1612

replies.bodyText:
I don't remember for certain, but it might have been an attempt to compensate for the fact that gRPC can take awhile to wake up after a connection becomes available.
How does backoff interact with the required network type? i.e. is the worker expected to start ASAP after the required network is available, regardless of backoff?
replies.author: gino-m

replies.bodyText: It will check for the constraint only after the required amount of time has passed based of last backoff delay. Only then it will start.
replies.author: shobhitagarwal1612

replies.bodyText: Is there no way to wake up the worker as soon as the connection becomes available? (@dturner?).  If not, perhaps LINEAR is a safer bet? As it's currently defined, retries will only occur at 10 sec, then 100 sec, and 1000 sec?
replies.author: gino-m

timeline.bodyText: Please add class JavaDoc with quick summary of what this base class provides.
timeline.author: gino-m

timeline.bodyText: Consider adding a noargs override of buildWorkerRquest() instead of passing null here with JavaDoc explaining the default behavior with noargs.
timeline.author: gino-m

timeline.message: Add javadoc comments and switch backoff policy to exponential
Create no-arg override of buildWorkerRequest()  and comments
Revert back to LINEAR policy and add a TODO
